awd_titl_txt: Planning: CIVIC-PG Track B: A Community-Designed Intersectional Food Access Rights for Marginalized communities (IFARM) Hub
awd_abstract_narration:
Food and housing security are linked contexts necessary for health, stability, and sustainability. In response to community-identified needs to improve food- and housing-related outcomes for people experiencing homelessness (PEH) in an urban setting. This planning grant will bring together expertise from PEH, civic, and academic collaborators to pilot a community-designed, systems-based intersectional resource hub. An Intersectional Food Access Rights for Marginalized communities (IFARM) Hub will be co-designed with PEH and community members, and co-located and linked with services, programs, and initiatives supporting various aspects of food and housing security. The IFARM Hub will bridge gaps between essential food resources and community needs for those experiencing food and housing insecurity in the underserved Glendale community on Salt Lake City’s west side. The IFARM Hub will use participatory, systems-based, intersectional approaches and methodologies to aggregate housing, health, social, transportation, and technology services to meaningfully increase healthy food and resource access. In collaboration with PEH and the nonprofit Green Phoenix Farm (GPF), the project will connect PEH with essential community resources, including nutritious foods, by extending GPF’s services and integrating it with other community-based organizations while concurrently assessing increased reach to broader housing- and food-insecure populations. Siting the IFARM Hub at the GPF, which employs women experiencing homelessness, leverages existing strengths of the farm’s off-grid solar array, which powers the farm’s refurbished shipping containers and reclaimed materials, including a walk-in cooler, produce packaging facility, computer lab, and office. The IFARM Hub will be housed in this shipping container-based infrastructure, inclusive of vertical space, to increase production, extend GPF’s seasonal growing capacity, and deepen integration with local communities.

The proposed research will work closely with PEH, community groups and key stakeholders to design mixed-methodology assessment plans to appraise the feasibility and effectiveness of the IFARM Hub. We will identify indicators of success from multiple stakeholders’ perspectives, with particular attention to needs identified by PEH, and anticipate increased access to nutrient-rich foods by larger numbers of PEH will be a key effectiveness outcome. Maintaining fidelity to community-engaged research practices, our research will identify key stakeholders in underrepresented communities, define success in health and social outcomes according to PEH and community collaborators, derive key metrics of health and social outcomes, identify current connectivity gaps, identify technological resources necessary for a sustainable community hub, and identify key facilitators and processes necessary for scaling the IFARM Hub for PEH to other comparable urban settings. 

This project is part of the CIVIC Innovation Challenge which is a collaboration of NSF, the Department of Energy's Vehicle Technology Office, and the Department of Homeland Security's Science and Technology Directorate and Federal Emergency Management Agency.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Our Stage 1 CIVIC Innovation planning grant was developed in response to community-identified needs to improve food-related outcomes for people experiencing homelessness. We initiated a Project Advisory Board composed of people experiencing homelessness, civic, and academic collaborators to refine a pilot plan for a community-designed Intersectional Food Access Rights for Marginalized communities (IFARM) Hub. The IFARM Hub would be located at our civic partner Wasatch Community Gardens’ Farm, which is an urban organic off-grid farm creating economic opportunities for women experiencing homelessness, with the aim to increase access to nutrient-rich fresh fruits and vegetables and improve nutrition security for people experiencing homelessness.

Inequitable access to fruits and vegetables is a significant social determinant of persistent and pervasive health disparities. As food and housing security are linked systems necessary for life, health, and sustainability, the IFARM Hub would bridge gaps in access to fruits and vegetables. Concurrently, this community-designed project would demonstrate the viability of creating a justice-oriented network connecting social, economic, environmental, food, and housing initiatives to increase positive outcomes for people experiencing homelessness in Utah’s Salt Lake Valley.

We examined the following research questions during Stage 1 to assess system opportunities and relevant outcome measures to determine feasibility and effectiveness, and potential for homeless service system integration to address improvements in nutrient-rich food access:

  • What stakeholders and underrepresented communities are needed for collaboration?
  • What are definitions of success in health and social outcomes according to people experiencing homelessness and community-based collaborators?
  • How can these outcomes be measured in meaningful and practical ways?
  • What resources are available that might be interconnected to improve these outcomes?
  • What are the technological resources necessary for a sustainable Hub?
  • What are the facilitators and barriers to scaling-up the IFARM Hub in other comparable mid-sized cities?

Multiple Project Advisory Board meetings were hosted at partner facilities, including Wasatch Community Gardens’ Farm and various homeless resource centers in Salt Lake County, Utah. Collaborative meetings featured research team members facilitating conversations and focus groups to attend to the above research questions. Project Advisory Board members reported difficult-to-navigate and fractured support systems as limitations to securing healthy food, employment, and housing outcomes for people experiencing homelessness. Additionally, based upon data from Project Advisory Board meetings, we identified three key mechanisms that contribute to the success of the Wasatch Community Gardens’ Farm job training program, including 1) informal peer support, 2) formal social networks, and 3) place-based connections. In addition to providing key insights informing the IFARM Hub design, Project Advisory Board members expressed enthusiasm and commitment to participating during Stage 2 with the aim of supporting and mentoring future IFARM participants.

The intellectual merit of this project was determining the degree to which an integrated systems approach increases access to, and utilization of, resources and services for people experiencing homelessness. Broader impacts and outcomes included:

  • Increased capacity for people experiencing homelessness to understand research and their rights and responsibilities as participants.
  • Improved knowledge and skills among Board members about all stages of community-based participatory research.
  • Amplification of perspectives and opinions of people experiencing homelessness at decision-making tables.
  • Enhanced cross-sector social service connections among existing resources that have been historically disjointed.
  • Capacity development for a ready-to-implement pilot.

Our team submitted a Stage 2 application to pilot the IFARM Hub in order to address local priorities for food security among people experiencing homelessness. The Hub was developed with substantial input from women experiencing homelessness, social service providers, and academics, with a long-term goal to be a sustainable solution locally, and an easily adapted model for other communities. Our Stage 2 pilot would determine:

  • How the Hub increases access to and consumption of fruits and vegetables for women at the Farm. 
  • The degree to which the Hub increases access to fruits and vegetables for people experiencing homelessness in the broader community.
  • Identify facilitators and challenges of food and social systems integration.

As states, counties, municipalities, and social services providers test different approaches to addressing and ultimately ending homelessness, advancing knowledge in this arena is urgent, both for communities and for the individuals who suffer through the lived realities of homelessness. The IFARM Hub was developed using an intersectional systems-integration model that featured substantial input from women experiencing homelessness, social service providers, and academics, with a long-term goal to be a sustainable solution locally, and a generalizable and easily adapted model for other communities across the U.S.

 


Last Modified: 06/14/2023
Modified by: Shannon Jones
